page.title: 01Part of the Vale of York
page.content: The aea is characterised by gently rolling,rich arable farmland, a patchwork of large irregular shaped fields, bounded by wire fences and occasional hedges. Now in wintertime, most cultivated fields are ploughed earth, with winter wheat newly sprouting here and there. A few cattle still graze the pastureland, but most animals are under cover in the farms. The main Leeds to York road cuts across the North west corner, but all other roads, some ancient travel ways, are surfaced with rubble and now interconnect scattered farmhouses solidly built from local limestone. About 15 percent of the area in two main patches is mixed, deciduous woodland, and scattered groups of trees occur everywhere. The most notable building, Hazelhurst castle once the home of the Vavaseur family
